title: Eliminating Variables
text: When both equations in the system have like variables of the second degree, solving them using elimination by addition is often easier than substitution. Generally, elimination is a far simpler method when the system involves only two equations in two variables (a two-by-two system), rather than a three-by-three system, as there are fewer steps.

Generally, elimination is a far simpler method when the system involves only two equations in two variables (a two-by-two system), rather than a three-by-three system, as there are fewer steps.

title: Common Terms between Equations
text: We observe that we can multiply $$2$$ to the first equation, so that $$2x^2$$ becomes a common term in both equations. This would allow us to solve the system by elimination.

title: Adding Equations
text: We observe that by adding the two equations together, we can remove the $$x^2$$ term. What is the equation obtained after adding the two equations?

title: Solving for $$y$$
text: With the equation $$2y^2+y+\frac{1}{8}-5000=0$$, we can solve for $$y$$. The y-coordinate found indicates a possible solution where an intersection may occur if the system of equations yield a feasible solution later on.
speech: With the equation  2 y squared, plus y plus 1 eighth minus 5000 is equal to 0 , we can solve for  y . The y-coordinate found indicates a possible solution where an intersection may occur if the system of equations yield a feasible solution later on.

title: Solving for $$y$$
text: We can use the quadratic formula $$y=\frac{\left(-b+-\sqrt{b^2-4a c}\right)}{2a}$$ to obtain the solutions. What are the $$y$$ coordinates?
speech: We can use the quadratic formula  y is equal to fraction, parentheses negative b plus negative the square root of b squared minus 4 a c end root , over, 2 a,   to obtain the solutions. What are the  y  coordinates?

title: Subsituting Possible Values
text: We substitute all possible $$y$$ coordinates back into one of the two equations to find the corresponding $$x$$ coordinate to each $$y$$ coordinate. Using any of the two equations work because the $$y$$ coordinate found is a solution to the system of equations. We usually use the equation that is easier to calculate the other coordinate with.

title: Substitution #1
text: Substituting $$y=\frac{-201}{4}$$ into $$y=2x^2$$. Find all possible corresponding $$x$$ coordinates.

title: Substitution #1
text: Divide $$2$$ on both sides. We observe that $$x^2$$ is equal to a negative number. Is there a real solution for $$x$$ to this equation?

title: Substitution #2
text: Take the square root on both sides. What are all the possible $$x$$ coordinates? You should rationalize the square roots in the denominator and simplify the expression.

title: Verifying the Number Of Intersections
text: We have found the coordinates of all intersections. How many are there?
